text: Applications

ACE 2-1

An angle whose measure is less than 90° is called an acute angle. An angle whose measure is greater than 90° and less than 180° is called an obtuse angle. Which of these angles are acute, which are obtuse, and which are right?

Acute angles are c and e.

Obtuse angles are a and f.

Right angles are b and d.
ACE 2-2

Snowboarders use angle measures to describe their flips and spins. Explain what a snowboarder would mean by each statement.

a. I did a 720

b. I did a 540

c. I did a 180

a. Two complete rotations

b. One and one-half complete rotations

c. One-half of a complete turn (essentially reversing directions)
ACE 2-3
Write an equation and find the measure of the angle labeled x, without measuring.

a. x = 180 - 30; x = 150°

b. x = 180 - 125; x = 55°

c. x = 90 - 27; x = 63°

d. x = 360 - 35; x = 225°
ACE 2-4
Decide whether each angle is closest to 30°, 60°, 90°, 120°, 150°, 180°, 270°, or 360° without measuring. Explain your reasoning.

a. 180°; half a rotation

b. 90°; ¼ of a rotation

c. 150°; More than 120˚ but less that 180˚

d. 60°; 2/3 of a right angle

e. 270°; ¾ of a rotation

f. 360°; almost a rotation

g. 120°; about 30˚ past a 90˚ rotation

h. 30°; 1/3 of a right angle
i. Classify each angle in ACE 4a-h as right, acute, or obtuse angles: c and g

Right angle: b

Acute Angles: d and h

Obtuse angles: c and g
ACE 2-5

A full turn is 360°. Find the fraction of a turn or number of turns for the given measurement.

a. 90°

b. 270°

c. 720°

d. How many degrees is 25/360 of a full turn?

a. ¼ of a turn

b. ¾ of a turn

c. 2 full turns

d. 25°
ACE 2-6

You can think of a right angle as one quarter of a complete rotation.

a. How many degrees is one-third of a quarter-rotation?

b. How many degrees is two times a quarter-rotation?

c. How many degrees is two and one third times a quarter-rotation?

a. 30°

b. 180°

c. 210°
ACE 2-7
A test question asked students to choose the larger angle. In one class, most students chose Angle 2. Do you agree? Why or why not?
No. Although the rays that make-up the drawing of angle 2 are longer, the angle measure of angle 1 indicates a greater turn and thus a larger angle.
ACE 2-8
Estimate the measure of each angle, then check your answers with an angle ruler or a protractor.

a. 50°

b. 130°

c. 21°

d. 210°

e. 170°
ACE 2-9

Draw an angle for each measure. Include an arch indicating the turn.

a. 45°

b. 25°

c. 180°

d. 200°
ACE 2-10

Without measuring, decide whether the angles in each pair have the same measure. If they do not, tell which angle has the greater measure. Then, find the measure of the angles with an angle ruler or protractor to check your work.

a. They do not have the same measure. Angle 1 is larger; angle 1 measures 60° and angle two measures 30°

b. Angle 1 and 2 have the same measure; 135°

c. They do not have the same measure. Angle 1 is larger; angle 1 measures 90° and angle 2 measures 45°
ACE 2-11
For each pair of angles, estimate the measure of each angle. Then, check your estimates by measuring with an angle ruler or a protractor.

a. ∠BVA = 45° and ∠AVB = 315°

b. ∠LKJ = 75° and ∠JKL = 285°

c. ∠RQP = 120° and ∠PQR = 240°

d. ∠ZYX = 160° and ∠XYZ = 200°
ACE 2-12
Ms. Cosgrove asked her students to estimate the measure of the angle shown.
Deshawn thought 150° would be a good estimate. Sofia said it should be 210°. Who is closer to the exact measurement? Explain.

Both students have given reasonable answers. However, when no direction of rotation is indicated, it is customary to focus on the angle as a union of two rays with common endpoint and measure between 0 and 180 degrees.
ACE 2-13
Use the diagram of the protractor below. ∠1 and ∠2 are called adjacent angles because they have a common vertex and a common side. Find the angle measures.

a. ∠1

b. ∠ 1 + ∠ 2

c. ∠ 1 + ∠ 2 + ∠ 3

d. ∠ 2

e. ∠ 2 + ∠ 3

f. ∠ 3

g. the complement of ∠1

h. the supplement of ∠1

i. the complement of ∠3

j. the supplement of ∠1 combined with ∠ 2

a. 60°

b. 110°

c. 150°

d. 50°

e. 90°

f. 40°

g. 30°; 90 - 60 = 30

h. 120°; 180 – 60 = 120

i. 50°; 90 – 40 = 50

j. 70°; 180 – 110 = 80
ACE 2-14
Use the diagram below to answer. Write an equation using the angle measures shown. Then, find the measures of ∠A and ∠B.

2x + 3x = 180 so 5x = 180; x = 36°.

The measure of ∠A is 108° (3 x 36). The measure of ∠B is 72° (2 x 36).
ACE 2-15
Use what you know about supplemental and vertical angles to find the measure of each angle. Show the equation you could use to find the value of y.

y + 3y = 180; 4y = 180 so y = 45°

Angle y and the angle vertical to it are 45°

Angle 3y (3 x 45) is 135° as is the angle vertical to it
ACE 2-16
Lines 1 and 2 are perpendicular, they meet at 90˚ angles.
a. Name all the pairs complementary angles.
∠v and ∠t; ∠x and ∠y
b. If the measure of ∠t twice the measure of ∠v, what is the measure of all of the angles? Explain.

Angles v and t add to 90˚. Angle t is 2v. So, v + 2v = 90. 3v = 90, so v = 30.

∠v = 30˚

∠t = 60˚ because it is 2v.

∠w = 90 ˚ because it is a right angle

∠x = 60˚ because it is vertical to ∠t

∠y= 30˚ because it is vertical to ∠v

∠z = 90 ˚ because it is a right angle
ACE 2-17
In the diagram below, lines L1 and L2 are parallel.
a. Find the degree measures of angles labeled a-g.
Angles b, e, and g measure 35°; angles  a, c, d, and f measure 145°.
b. Name the pairs of opposite or vertical angles in the figure.
Vertical angle pairs: ∠a and ∠c; ∠b and  the 35° angle; ∠e and ∠g; and ∠d and ∠f.
c. Name three pairs of supplementary angles in the figure.

There are many pairs of supplementary angles including:

∠a and 35˚; ∠a and ∠b; ∠b and ∠c; ∠c and 35˚;

∠e and ∠d; ∠d and ∠g; ∠g and ∠f; ∠f and ∠e;

∠a and ∠e; ∠a and ∠g; ∠b and ∠d; ∠b and ∠f.
ACE 2-18
Line 1 and Line 2 are not parallel lines. They are intersected by L3. Explain what you know about the measure of each angle.

∠a is vertical to the 105˚ angle, which make ∠a = 105˚

∠b is supplementary to ∠a, which makes it 180 – 105 = 75˚

∠d is vertical to ∠b, which make ∠d = 75˚

Because L1 and L2 are not parallel, we cannot find the measure of angles e, f, g, and h without measuring. If we measure one of the angles, we could use vertical and supplemental relationships to find the other three measures.
ACE 2-19
In the diagram below, L1 and L2 are parallel lines. Without measuring, find the measure of each angle and explain how you know.

a = 130° because the 50° angle and angle a are supplemental angles and their measures equal 180° when added together

b = 50° because it is vertical to the 50° angle and vertical angles have the same measure

c = 130° because it is vertical to angle a which is 130°

d = 130° because L1 and L2 are parallel so when they are intersected by a transversal, the two sets of 4 angles formed will be equivalent

e = 50° because it is equal to angle b

f = 130° because it is equal to angle c

g = 50° because it is vertical to e so therefore equal to e
Connections
ACE 2-20

The number 360 has many factors. This may be why it was chosen for the number of degrees in a full turn.

a. List all of the factors of 360.

b. Find the prime factorization of 360.
ACE 2-21

At the start of each hour, the minute hand points straight up at 12. In parts a.– f., determine the angle between the minute hand at the start of an hour and the minute hand after the given amount of time passes. For each situation, sketch the angle and indicate the rotation of the minute hand.

a. 15 minutes

b. 30 minutes

c. 20 minutes

d. one hour

e. 5 minutes

f. one and one-half hours

a. 90°

b. 180°

c. 120°

d. 360°

e. 30°

f. 540°
ACE 2-22

Write each fraction as a decimal.

a. 2/5

b. 3/4

c. 3/10

d. 1/4

e. 7/10

f. 7/20

g. 4/5

h. 7/8

i. 15/20

j. 3/5

a. 2/5 = 4/10 = 0.4.

b. ¾ = 75/100 = 0.75.

c. 0.3

d. ¼ = 25/100 = 0.25

e. 0.7

f. 7/20 = 35/100 = 0.35

g. 4/5 = 8/10 = 0.8

h. 0.875

i. 15/20 = 75/100 = 0.75

j. 3/5 = 6/10 = 0.6
ACE 2-23
Find the value for n.
ACE 2-24
The members of the skateboard club were practicing. They wanted to work on increasing the angle rotation each member did when standing and turning their skateboards. They recorded their rotations:
a. What is the median of the turns that the club members can make on their boards?
a. Median is 40°
b. What is the mean of the turns that the club members can make on their boards? Three weeks later, they each tried a stand and turn again. They recorded their rotations again:
c. How does their new data compare?
c. the new data has the same median, mean, and range (80° between the min and the max.) However, the data is clustered differently with bigger gaps between the clusters of members.
ACE 2-25
Find a value of n that makes the equation true.
ACE 2-26

Multiple Choice

Which of the following shaded regions is not a representation of 4/12?
ACE 2-27
For each equation or inequality, find the value of x.
Extensions
ACE 2-28

Design a new polar coordinate grid for Four in a Row in Problem 1.2. Play your game with a friend or family member. What ideas did you use to design your new grid? Explain. How does playing on your grid compare to playing on the original grids?
Variations of the Four in a Row game could take a variety of forms—more concentric circles, different benchmark angle patterns (e.g., multiples of 10°), or others that we haven’t imagined.
ACE 2-29

List all polygons in the Shapes Set from the manipulatives kit or Learning Aid Template: Shapes Set that have the following characteristics:

a. only right-angle corners.

b. only obtuse-angle corners.

c. only acute-angle corners.

d. at least one angle of each type — acute, right, and obtuse.

a. Figures B, G, H, and J have only right angle corners.

b. Figures C, D, E, and F have only obtuse angle corners.

c. Figures A and P have only acute angle corners.

d. Figures Q and S have at least one angle of each type.
ACE 2-30

A compass is a tool used in wilderness navigation. On a compass, North is assigned the direction label 0°, East is 90°, South is 180°, and West is 270°. Directions that are between those labels are assigned degree labels such as NE at 45°, for example.

a. What degree measures would you expect for the direction south-southwest? For north-northwest?

b. A ship at sea is on a heading of 300°. Approximately what direction is it traveling?

a. ∠SSW is 202.5°, ∠NNW is 337.5°

b. The ship is traveling in a direction 30° north of due west
ACE 2-31
Major airports label runways with the numbers by the compass heading. For example, a plane on runway 15 is on a compass heading of 150°. A plane on runway 9 is on a compass heading of 90°.

a. What is the runway number of a plane that is taking off on a heading due west? On a heading due east?

b. What is the compass heading of a plane landing on runway 6? On runway 12?

c. Each actual runway has two direction labels. The label depends on the direction in which a landing or taking off plane is headed. How are those labels related to each other?

a. The runway heading due west is 27; heading due east is 9.

b. Runway 6 implies a compass heading of 60°. Runway 12 implies a compass heading of 120°.

c. Labels for runways in opposite directions differ by 18, related to the 180° difference in their directions.
ACE 2-32

Soledad extended the sides of the green parallelogram below. She looked at the vertical angles and supplementary angles. Soledad claims that the opposite angles in a parallelogram will always have the same measures. Do you agree? Explain.

Yes. The lines are all parallel, so opposite angles are equal to the same size vertical angles. In the drawing we can see all of the angles indicated by the blue arcs are the same measures and all of the angles indicated by the red arcs have the same measure. The adjacent angles on the parallelogram are supplementary. We can see this because they are the same as the measures of an internal angle and external angle that add to 180˚.
ACE 2-33
In the parallelogram, find the measure of each numbered angle.
Angles 1, 3, and 5 are all 63°; angles 2 and 4 are both 117°.
ACE 2-34
In the triangle ABC, a line has been drawn through vertex A, parallel to side BC.

a. What is the sum of the measures of angles 1, 2, and 3?

b. Explain why angle 1 has the same measure as angle 4 and why angle 3 has the same measure as angle 5.

c. How can you use the results of parts (a) and (b) to show that the angle sum of a triangle is 180°?

a. 180°

b. Both pairs of angles are on opposite  sides of a transversal between parallel  lines.

c. The angles 1, 2, and 3 have the same measures as angles 6, 2, and 5  respectively, and angles 6, 2, and 5 are  the angles of a triangle. Since the sum  of the measures of angles 1, 2, and 3  is the measure of a straight angle, the  sum of the measures of those angles is 180°. This means that the sum of the  measures of angles 6, 2, and 5 is also  180°.
